items.text: I secretly believe that most people don't appreciate how special I really am.
items.rationale: Reflects a covert sense of grandiosity and unrecognized specialness central to hypersensitive narcissistic egocentrism.

items.text: When I walk into a room, I assume people are forming opinions about me.
items.rationale: Self-referential thinking and the assumption of being the focus of others' attention is a hallmark of egocentrism.

items.text: I often feel that my problems are more complex and unique than what other people deal with.
items.rationale: Belief in the uniqueness of one's own suffering reflects narcissistic self-centeredness.

items.text: I find it hard to be genuinely happy for someone else's success because I feel it highlights my own shortcomings.
items.rationale: Inability to celebrate others due to self-referential comparison is a core egocentric feature of covert narcissism.

items.text: When someone else is talking about their day, I often redirect the conversation back to myself.
items.rationale: Behavioral indicator of self-focused conversational patterns reflecting egocentrism.

items.text: I tend to interpret other people's actions primarily in terms of how they affect me.
items.rationale: Self-as-center-of-reference in interpreting social events is definitional of egocentrism.

items.text: Deep down, I feel entitled to more recognition than I currently receive.
items.rationale: Covert entitlement and a sense of being undervalued reflect hypersensitive narcissistic egocentrism.

items.text: I sometimes fantasize about being recognized for talents that others have overlooked.
items.rationale: Grandiose fantasy life centered on unrecognized merit is characteristic of covert narcissistic egocentrism.

items.text: People close to me have told me I make everything about myself.
items.rationale: Third-person behavioral observation of self-centeredness directly taps egocentrism.

items.text: I feel resentful when others don't acknowledge the sacrifices I've made for them.
items.rationale: Expectation of recognition for one's contributions reflects entitled self-focus.

items.text: I often compare myself to others and feel I deserve what they have.
items.rationale: Envious social comparison rooted in a sense of entitlement is a core egocentric narcissistic feature.

items.text: When a group makes plans, I feel frustrated if my preferences aren't prioritized.
items.rationale: Expectation that one's own needs should take precedence in group settings reflects egocentrism.

items.text: I sometimes feel like the world owes me something, even though I can't explain why.
items.rationale: Vague entitlement maps to egocentrism but the diffuse quality could also reflect general dissatisfaction or depressive cognition.

items.text: I have difficulty truly listening to others because my own thoughts feel more pressing.
items.rationale: Self-preoccupation interfering with empathic listening maps to egocentrism, though could also reflect attentional difficulties.

items.text: When someone criticizes me, I dwell on it for days and feel deeply wounded.
items.rationale: While the self-focused rumination reflects egocentrism, the emotional wounding and prolonged distress strongly overlap with Oversensitivity.

items.text: My feelings are easily hurt, even by comments that others seem to shrug off.
items.rationale: Heightened emotional reactivity to minor interpersonal slights is the core of hypersensitive narcissistic oversensitivity.

items.text: I often feel slighted or disrespected in situations where no offense was intended.
items.rationale: Perceiving slights where none exist reflects the hypervigilant sensitivity characteristic of this factor.

items.text: I tend to withdraw from people after feeling even mildly rejected.
items.rationale: Withdrawal in response to perceived rejection is a behavioral hallmark of hypersensitive narcissistic oversensitivity.

items.text: I am very attuned to any hint of disapproval in other people's tone of voice.
items.rationale: Hypervigilance to social cues of disapproval directly taps the oversensitivity construct.

items.text: A casual remark from a friend can ruin my entire day if I interpret it as negative.
items.rationale: Disproportionate emotional impact from minor social interactions reflects core oversensitivity.

items.text: I avoid social situations because I'm afraid of being judged or embarrassed.
items.rationale: Social avoidance driven by fear of negative evaluation is characteristic of the oversensitive narcissistic pattern.

items.text: When people laugh in a group, part of me wonders if they're laughing at me.
items.rationale: Paranoid-like referential thinking about being mocked reflects hypersensitive interpersonal vigilance.

items.text: I replay conversations in my head, analyzing whether I said something that made me look foolish.
items.rationale: Post-event rumination about social performance reflects the anxious self-monitoring of oversensitivity.

items.text: I feel deeply ashamed when I make even a small mistake in front of others.
items.rationale: Intense shame reactions to minor public errors are a defining feature of hypersensitive narcissistic vulnerability.

items.text: I can sense when someone's attitude toward me has shifted, even slightly, and it bothers me greatly.
items.rationale: Acute interpersonal radar for relational shifts combined with distress directly maps to oversensitivity.

items.text: Being excluded from a social event, even one I didn't want to attend, feels like a personal rejection.
items.rationale: Interpreting exclusion as personal rejection regardless of actual desire to participate reflects hypersensitive processing.

items.text: I often hold back my opinions because I'm afraid of how others will react.
items.rationale: Self-silencing driven by anticipated negative reactions reflects the inhibited, oversensitive narcissistic style.

items.text: I sometimes feel emotionally overwhelmed in situations that don't seem to bother anyone else.
items.rationale: General emotional overwhelm maps to oversensitivity but could also reflect broader emotional dysregulation or neuroticism.

items.text: I need a lot of reassurance from others that they still care about me.
items.rationale: Reassurance-seeking maps to oversensitivity but could also reflect attachment anxiety independent of narcissistic dynamics.

items.text: When someone doesn't acknowledge my contribution, I feel both hurt and angry that I'm being overlooked.
items.rationale: The hurt component maps to Oversensitivity, but the anger about being overlooked and the expectation of acknowledgment strongly overlap with Egocentrism.
